ygData.subject: Re: New file uploaded to neat
ygData.msgSnippet: Thanks, Ken. Novelty search really does much better than fitness search in this domain. I agree that HyperNEAT allows too much recurrence in this particular

Thanks, Ken. Novelty search really does much better than fitness 
search in=
 this domain. I agree that HyperNEAT allows too much 
recurrence in this pa=
rticular substrate (there are no restrictions), 
but I am actually doing a =
more interesting thing - I exploit the fact 
that as the time constants and=
 biases "pictures" through the 
substrate are simple, the activity pattern =
of the neural network is 
also simple. Then as the CPPNs complexify, so do =
the activity 
patterns of the CTRNN substrate. So too much recurrence is no=
t much 
of a problem. Perhaps I am wrong. Maybe output->output connections =

are not necessary? Or I can make it like a typical feed-forward 
network, =
similar to the one presented in the HyperNEAT playing 
checkers paper? I'll=
 try this stuff. But this essentialy cuts out a 
lot of the search space wh=
ere solutions may exist. It is a kind of 
dilemma. On the one side, HyperNE=
AT without restrictions in the 
substrate (except trivial things like input=
s do not have incoming 
links) can find perfect solutions, but on the other=
 side, that search 
space is too big and probably intractable. I believe th=
at the 
dynamics of CPPN evolution is very different than direct encodigs, =

like for example the mating and mutation causes entirely different 
things=
 to happen. If there was not speciation, I doubt that HyperNEAT 
would have=
 the same performance as it currently has. 
Yet this is about novelty searc=
h combined with an indirect encoding. 
The good thing is that it is indeed =
very effective and it is true 
that the ladder of complexity is climbed up =
more efficiently this 
way. But I also think that this can be improved in s=
ome way, to be 
better. 

Peter




--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth S=
tanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Nice work, Peter, it's a very nice demons=
tration.  I also saw the
> humanoid shuffle backwards.  It does seem easier=
 to do that than go
> forwards.  
> 
> My guess is that the behavior charac=
terization of final (x,y,z)
> probably conflates too many behaviors.  The t=
rick in walking is in
> oscillation, so the proper stepping stone needs to =
have some ability
> to oscillate, regardless of where its head ends up.  I'=
d also guess
> that the substrate also could be simplified.  I believe that=
 it is
> allowing so much recurrence that it is very difficult to produce a=

> stable system.
> 
> You know what would be cool is if you could specify =
the behavior
> characterization yourself as the user, like if the program p=
rovided
> all the possible state variables and you could select what to 
in=
clude
> in the characterization.
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com,=
 "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@>
> wrote:
> >
> > Hey I am glad that=
 you like that stuff, it was around in my 
computer 
> > a whole week but I=
 decided to upload a binary just before a day. 
Let 
> > me explain the det=
ails behind it. As you are probably familiar 
with 
> > the other NEVH shit=
 this code does the same but uses another NEAT 
> > implememtation and nove=
lty search. (steady state evolution). 
> > I've seen some dolls actually wa=
lking, but backwards. Kind of 
weird. 
> > I guess it is the easier way, th=
ough :) 
> > The behavior characterization is (as Peter B proposed) the fin=
al 
XYZ 
> > location of the head. The distance is simply the eucldian 
dis=
tance 
> > between those points. I agree that there are many options and I =

am 
> > trying out many different BCs (behavior characterizations). But 
t=
his 
> > one works well. 
> > The nodes in the substrate are arranged in a =
geometric way to 
reflect 
> > the body's geometry in space. Each output co=
rresponds to a joint 
> > angle. Arms and legs are placed symmetrically in =
the left and 
right 
> > sides. The head (neck joint) is placed above them =
in the center. 
> > Outputs are drawn in green. Inputs (head velocity) are =
drawn in 
red. 
> > Hidden nodes are drawn in yellow. Ergh I see it is upsi=
de-down 
but 
> > HyperNEAT doesn't care about this anyway :) 
> > The 5th =
input to the CPPN is the distance from 0, 0 in node-
specific 
> > data and=
 the distance between the 2 points when computing the 
weight 
> > of the c=
onnection between 2 nodes. Just like in your paper, the 
same 
> > bias. 
>=
 > 
> > Peter
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "David D'Ambrosio" <dda=
mbro84@> 
wrote:
> > >
> > > Wow, this looks really cool Petar.  I thought =
it would be awhile
> > > before we saw HyperNEAT and novelty search combine=
d.  I ran it 
> > while I
> > > was working on other stuff for a bit over 5=
0,000 evaluations, 
> > checking
> > > in on it periodically.  The behavior=
al diversity was really
> > > impressive: I got guys that were taking baby =
steps and guys 
that 
> > were
> > > doing yoga poses (I swear one of them =
did "the chair"), 
although 
> > there
> > > were still a good number of re=
peats, especially near the end 
> > (falling
> > > onto theirs knees seemed=
 pretty common).  No one that I saw had 
a 
> > good
> > > walking gait, bu=
t I guess it's possible that one could have 
when I
> > > wasn't watching, =
perhaps we need an option to browse the 
archive. 
> > I'm
> > > curious ab=
out a few things, if you wouldn't mind sharing:
> > > 
> > > -What did you =
use as a novelty metric?  It's seems like there 
are a
> > > number of viab=
le options here.
> > > 
> > > -What do the nodes on the substrate mean, and=
 are they just on 
a 
> > flat
> > > plane?  I used your older version when=
 it was first released, 
and 
> > if I
> > > remember right the two on the =
left are inputs and the stuff on 
the
> > > right is various joints, but I =
wanted to make sure.
> > > 
> > > -Similarly, what do you use as the 5th in=
put on the CPPN?
> > > 
> > > Thanks,
> > > David D'Ambrosio
> > >
